TopicTitle: Ask the Mods questions about the Forums!

Articles.Content: What forum engine is this running on. I've seen many forums with the exact same layout. Malwarebytes and the KSP forums are the same layout.

> 
> 
> 5 hours ago, Arco123 said:
> 
> 
> What forum engine is this running on. I've seen many forums with the exact same layout. Malwarebytes and the KSP forums are the same layout.
> 

Invision Power Services (IPS)

> 
> 
> 12 hours ago, Arco123 said:
> 
> 
> What forum engine is this running on. I've seen many forums with the exact same layout. Malwarebytes and the KSP forums are the same layout.
> 

> 
> 
> 6 hours ago, Deddly said:
> 
> 
> Invision Power Services (IPS)
> 

As deddly said, Invision, there is a link at the very bottom of (almost) every page to it.

Is there a reason why the Privacy Policy popup keeps coming back? It actually just popped up wholesale over a thread link (one of these, just picked a random thread to show what I meant).  

<iframe allowfullscreen="" data-controller="core.front.core.autosizeiframe" data-embedauthorid="188222" data-embedcontent="" data-embedid="embed5818364257" scrolling="no" src="https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/190899-which-features-will-you-forgo-for-an-early-release/&do=embed" style="height:214px;max-width:502px;"></iframe>

^ rather than seeing the thread preview in the box, I just got a privacy notice popup there instead.  

On EVERY single forum tab I had open it suddenly came back up.  

It seems like it's on a cooldown or something, it goes away for maybe a day? Then I have to get rid of it all over again. We're 13 days in, I've clearly accepted it.

I seem to be encountering a bug with the 'someone linked to your content' notifications.

[@Laie](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/110461-laie/) recently adopted an old challenge of mine, and he linked to my thread in his <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr>. I received a notification about this and posted something like 'hey thanks for taking up my challenge' on the thread. Since then I've got several more identical notifications about Laie linking my content - all of them direct me to the <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr> of his thread. I think something might be triggering a notification every time he posts on that thread, but I can't tell if it actually directly correlates. Could one of you take a look? [Here's the thread](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/topic/191034-fastest-juno-powered-airplane/) in case you need it.

[@RealKerbal3x](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/183830-realkerbal3x/) It seems that the <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr> of that thread has been edited quite a few times.  I believe you're receiving the notifications when he edits the <abbr title="1. Original Post(er). The first post in a thread, or the person who posted it. 2. Overpowered. A part or mechanic that upsets game balance by being too powerful.">OP</abbr>.  I'll check with out IT and see if there's anything that can be done.

Not a really serious question but did [@Vanamonde](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/27914-vanamonde/)'s icon change. I don't recall that face...
Nice people have made several of them for me and I rotate them from time to time, [@The Doodling Astronaut](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/196529-the-doodling-astronaut/).

I'm just curious about this, but can a moderator change their own username? If I remember correctly, users are limited to 1 username change. But what about moderators?

Can they change their usernames themselves, or do they need a Global Moderator to do that?

As for Global Moderators, can *they* change their usernames as well?

Sorry for all the questions.

Regular moderators don't have the ability to change their own or anyone else's names, and I imagine they would have the same one change limit, but I don't really know, because it's never been asked ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif ":)")

Also, Global moderators can't do it either, except for [@Vanamonde](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/27914-vanamonde/), because even the forum software is afraid of Vanamonde.
Yeah, afraid that I'll fat-finger something and wreck it.

**Edited <time datetime="2020-02-07T22:45:13Z" title="02/07/2020 10:45  PM" data-short="4 yr">February 7, 2020</time> by Bej Kerman**
How do i post a question, i have questions left unanswered, but can't figure out how to start a question!

Welcome to the forum [@Getgotyeet](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/index.php?/profile/202681-getgotyeet/), there are a few methods but this is the one I mostly use;  

On the forum front page you have the option to 'start a new topic'  - You are then presented with options for where the thread will be located. If you were going to ask a question about playing KSP then you would select 'gameplay questions' then continue. You should see a topic setup screen and can ask away.

How did this forum get to this stage. (Grow)

And, (Slightly off topic.) how did you guys become mods? Were you normal members before?

> 
> 
> 3 minutes ago, Arco123 said:
> 
> 
> Were you normal members before?
> 

Define "Normal".... ![:sticktongue:](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue2.gif ":sticktongue:")  
(sorry... couldn't resist... hehehe)

Normal: 

Normal person [behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Behavior "Behavior") that can be normal for an individual (intrapersonal normality) when it is consistent with the most common behaviour for that person. Normal is also used to describe individual behaviour that conforms to the most common behaviour in society (known as [conformity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conformity "Conformity")). Definitions of normality vary by person, time, place, and situation – it changes along with changing societal standards and [norms](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norm_%28social%29 "Norm (social)"). Normal behavior is often only recognized in contrast to [abnormality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abnormality_%28behavior%29 "Abnormality (behavior)"). In its simplest form, normality is seen as good while abnormality is seen as bad.^[\[1\]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Normality_%28behavior%29#cite_note-1)^ Someone being seen as normal or not normal can have social ramifications, such as being [included](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inclusion_%28value_and_practice%29 "Inclusion (value and practice)"), excluded or [stigmatized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_stigma "Social stigma") by larger society.

I was just kidding... hehehe.  

I'm not really qualified to answer. I'm not a moderator. But to the best of my knowledge, all of them started as regular forum members, yes.
